javaslang.control

Interface Try<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - Value type in the case of success.
    All Superinterfaces:
    FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>, Iterable<T>, Kind<Try<?>,T>, TraversableOnce<T>, Value<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Failure, Success

    public interface Try<T>
extends TraversableOnce<T>, Value<T>, FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>, Kind<Try<?>,T>
    An implementation similar to Scala's Try control.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  Try.CheckedConsumer<T>
      A Consumer which may throw.
      static interface  Try.CheckedFunction<T,R>
      A Function which may throw.
      static interface  Try.CheckedPredicate<T>
      A Predicate which may throw.
      static interface  Try.CheckedRunnable
      A Runnable which may throw.
      static interface  Try.CheckedSupplier<R>
      A Supplier which may throw.

        static <T> Try<T> of(Try.CheckedSupplier<T> supplier)
        Creates a Try of a CheckedSupplier.
        Type Parameters:
        T - Component type
        Parameters:
        supplier - A checked supplier
        Returns:
        Success(supplier.get()) if no exception occurs, otherwise Failure(throwable) if an exception occurs calling supplier.get().

      • run

        static Try<Void> run(Try.CheckedRunnable runnable)
        Creates a Try of a CheckedRunnable.
        Parameters:
        runnable - A checked runnable
        Returns:
        Success(null) if no exception occurs, otherwise Failure(throwable) if an exception occurs calling runnable.run().

      • recover

        Try<T> recover(Function<Throwable,? extends T> f)
        Returns this, if this is a Success, otherwise tries to recover the exception of the failure with f, i.e. calling Try.of(() -> f.apply(throwable)).
        Parameters:
        f - A recovery function taking a Throwable
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • recoverWith

        Try<T> recoverWith(Function<Throwable,Try<T>> f)
        Returns this, if this is a Success, otherwise tries to recover the exception of the failure with f, i.e. calling f.apply(cause.getCause()). If an error occurs recovering a Failure, then the new Failure is returned.
        Parameters:
        f - A recovery function taking a Throwable
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • failed

        Try<Throwable> failed()
        Returns Success(throwable) if this is a Failure(throwable), otherwise a Failure(new UnsupportedOperationException("Success.failed()")) if this is a Success.
        Returns:
        a new Try

        Consumes the throwable if this is a Failure, otherwise returns this Success.
        Parameters:
        f - A Consumer
        Returns:
        a new Failure, if this is a Failure and the consumer throws, otherwise this, which may be a Success or a Failure.

      • filter

        Try<T> filter(Predicate<? super T> predicate)

        Returns this if this is a Failure or this is a Success and the value satisfies the predicate.

        Returns a new Failure, if this is a Success and the value does not satisfy the Predicate or an exception occurs testing the predicate.

        Specified by:
        filter in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • filterTry

        Try<T> filterTry(Try.CheckedPredicate<? super T> predicate)

      • filterOption

        Try<Option<T>> filterOption(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Returns a new FilterMonadic consisting of Some elements if there are elements which satisfy the given predicate. Otherwise the results contains one None element. Please note, that the result will not contain a mixture of Some and None elements.

        This method is intended to be used with monadic types which may have only one value, e.g. Lazy and Match (resp. MatchMonad).

        Specified by:
        filterOption in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        a new FilterMonadic instance

      • flatMapM

        <U> Try<U> flatMapM(Function<? super T,? extends Kind<? extends Try<?>,? extends U>> mapper)
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Flat maps the elements of this elements of a new type preserving their order, if any.

        This method effectively does call 

        this.flatMap((Function<? super T, ? extends M<? extends U>>) mapper);
        It exists, because Java's type system (the lack of higher-order kinds) does not allow us to define an interface containing the mentioned flatMap method.
        Specified by:
        flatMapM in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - Component type of the flat mapped FilterMonadic
        Parameters:
        mapper - A mapper.
        Returns:
        a flat mapped FilterMonadic

      • flatten

        Try<Object> flatten()
        Description copied from interface: FilterMonadic
        Flattens a FilterMonadic.

        The semantics may vary from class to class. The commonality is, that some kind of wrapped state is recursively unwrapped.

        Example: 

        ((1, 2), 3, (4, (5, 6))).flatten() = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
        Specified by:
        flatten in interface FilterMonadic<Try<?>,T>
        Returns:
        A flattened version of this FilterMonadic.

      • mapTry

        <U> Try<U> mapTry(CheckedFunction1<? super T,? extends U> mapper)
        Runs the given checked function if this is a Success, passing the result of the current expression to it. If this expression is a Failure then it'll return a new Failure of type R with the original exception. The main use case is chaining checked functions using method references: 
         
 Try.of(() -> 0)
    .mapTry(x -> 1 / x); // division by zero
        Type Parameters:
        U - The new component type
        Parameters:
        mapper - A checked function
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • peek

        Try<T> peek(Consumer<? super T> action)
        Applies the action to the value of a Success or does nothing in the case of a Failure.
        Specified by:
        peek in interface TraversableOnce<T>
        Parameters:
        action - A Consumer
        Returns:
        this Try

      • iterator

        default Iterator<T> iterator()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<T>

      • andThen

        default Try<Void> andThen(Try.CheckedRunnable runnable)
        Runs the given runnable if this is a Success, otherwise returns this Failure. Shorthand for flatMap(ignored -> Try.run(runnable)). The main use case is chaining runnables using method references: 
         
 Try.run(A::methodRef).andThen(B::methodRef).andThen(C::methodRef);
        Please note that these lines are semantically the same: 
         
 Try.run(() -> { doStuff(); })
    .andThen(() -> { doMoreStuff(); })
    .andThen(() -> { doEvenMoreStuff(); });

 Try.run(() -> {
     doStuff();
     doMoreStuff();
     doEvenMoreStuff();
 });
        Parameters:
        runnable - A checked runnable
        Returns:
        a new Try

      • andThen

        Try<T> andThen(Try.CheckedConsumer<? super T> consumer)
        Runs the given checked consumer if this is a Success, passing the result of the current expression to it. If this expression is a Failure then it'll return a new Failure of type T with the original exception. The main use case is chaining checked functions using method references: 
         
 Try.of(() -> 100)
    .andThen(i -> System.out.println(i));
        Parameters:
        consumer - A checked consumer taking a single argument.
        Returns:
        a new Try
